Realizing the Oruscar's centuries-long inaction against this corruption, Trazyn contemplated intervening himself, driven by his own motives and amusement. Using the Orrery, he identified Cadia as a focal point in the galaxy's turmoil, home to ancient Necron Pylons crucial for containing the Immaterium.

During the final battle for Cadia, Trazyn intervened, aiding Imperial forces and ultimately acquiring Ursarkar E. Creed for his collection before Cadia fell to chaos. His actions showcased the Orrery's dual role as both a strategic tool and a source of historical insight, highlighting its profound influence on galactic events.

Despite the Orrery's immense power, the Oruscar Dynasty exercises caution, viewing themselves as stewards rather than conquerors. Their careful management aims to preserve cosmic balance, contrasting sharply with Trazyn's more whimsical and opportunistic approach.

The Orrery's complex mechanisms and the conflicts surrounding its use underscore its pivotal role in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, where its manipulation can reshape the fate of entire star systems and civilizations, driving the ongoing struggle for control among Necrons, aliens, and Imperium alike.
39.name: The Celestial Orrery

40.content: The Fabricator Locum is a title given to a high ranking techpriest within the Martian Mechanicum, who serve as ruling deputy of a Forge World, subordinate to the Fabricator General. While most Forge Worlds have their own respective Fabricator-Generals and Fabricator-Locums, it is the Fabricator-Locum of Mars who serves as the de facto second in command of the entire Mechanicum after the Fabricator-General of the Red Planet itself.
40.name: The Fabricator Locum

41.content:
The Adeptus Arbites, galactic enforcers of Imperial Law within the Imperium of Man, serve as an unwavering judicial and paramilitary force across countless worlds. Recruited primarily from the orphaned progeny of high-ranking Imperial servants, trained in the Schola Progenium, these Arbitrators are molded into relentless instruments of the Emperor’s will.

Operating under the Lex Imperialis, a millennia-old body of laws, Arbitrators and Judges uphold justice through the vast and intricate Book of Judgement. Despite its complexity and occasional ambiguities, they rigorously interpret and apply its decrees, often resorting to severe measures, including preemptive vigilantism, to maintain order. Their presence is marked by imposing precinct-fortresses that dominate the skyline of Imperial worlds, instilling fear even in planetary governors.

The Adeptus Arbites is structured into Judges, who handle legal matters, and Arbitrators, who execute enforcement and apprehension duties. These roles intertwine at senior levels, where officers engage in forensic investigation and cyber-warfare, wielding authority that extends across entire planets. Their incorruptible nature also makes them sought-after allies of the Inquisition, although clashes can occur due to differing methods and priorities.

Arbitrators, empowered by Judges and Marshals, wield immense authority and the backing of the Astra Militarum, ensuring compliance through fear and force. Their influence spans from routine patrols and investigations to quelling planetary uprisings, ensuring that all, including planetary leaders, remain accountable under Imperial Law. Such uncompromising adherence to justice serves as a bulwark against threats to Imperial order, safeguarding the Imperium's stability in times of crisis.

Collaboration with the Imperial Inquisition is common, with Arbitrators providing critical support in combat and intelligence operations. This partnership often sees Arbitrators embedded in Inquisitorial retinues, leveraging their expertise and loyalty against the Imperium’s foes. However, instances of corruption within the ranks necessitate Inquisitorial intervention to purge traitors and maintain the integrity of the Arbites.
41.name: The Adeptus Arbites

42.content:
The Lex Imperialis, also known as Imperial Law, stands as the enduring legal framework of the Imperium of Man, spanning millennia of evolution and governance. Initially shaped by the decrees of the Emperor during the Great Crusade and refined through subsequent amendments by figures like Roboute Guilliman, it governs all aspects of life within the Imperium, blending civil and criminal statutes into a cohesive whole.

Enforced primarily by the Adeptus Arbites and the Inquisition, Imperial Law serves as a divine mandate, reflecting the Emperor's will and demanding unwavering obedience. The Adeptus Arbites function as the enforcers of these laws, operating as a galaxy-spanning police force from fortified Precinct Fortresses. Their authority is bolstered by the Book of Judgement, a vast repository of legal precedents housed on Terra, which guides Arbites Judges in dispensing justice across Human-settled worlds.

Beyond the Arbites, the Inquisition plays a crucial role in upholding Imperial Law, operating independently to root out threats to Imperial stability. Divided into Puritan and Radical factions, the Inquisition interprets and enforces the laws with varying degrees of strictness, reflecting internal ideological tensions. Puritans uphold the letter of Imperial Law and traditional beliefs without compromise, while Radicals adopt more flexible interpretations and methods, risking accusations of heresy in pursuit of their goals.

Imperial Law embodies a blend of secular governance and religious doctrine, viewed not just as legal statutes but as expressions of divine will. It mandates centralized authority under the High Lords of Terra, ensuring uniformity of law while allowing for adaptations to local conditions overseen by planetary governors. Enforcement by the Adeptus Arbites is marked by stringent measures to maintain order, with punishments ranging from fines to execution, particularly severe when crimes threaten Imperial stability or challenge the spiritual order.

Crucially, Imperial Law addresses crimes such as heresy and sedition, seen as existential threats to the Imperium. Heresy involves deviating from the Ecclesiarchy's doctrines, while sedition targets actions aimed at undermining Imperial authority. Both are swiftly and decisively handled by the Arbites and Inquisition, underscoring the Imperium's uncompromising stance on internal threats.

While Imperial Law maintains a rigid framework, it allows for interpretative flexibility, particularly within the Inquisition. Radicals may justify unorthodox methods in pursuit of broader objectives, albeit under strict scrutiny to prevent deviation into heresy. This balance between rigidity and flexibility ensures the Imperium's stability while addressing diverse challenges across its vast territories.
42.name: The Lex Imperialis

43.content:
T'au, the homeworld of the T'au species located in the T'au star system, stands as the paramount Sept within the T'au Empire. Governed by the High Council under the leadership of Ethereal Supreme Aun'Va, T'au holds unrivaled political significance. Even as the T'au Empire expanded across the stars, T'au retained its cultural centrality and bureaucratic core. Its warm, arid climate influences T'au's colonization strategy, steering T'au settlers towards planets like T'ros with similar environmental conditions.

Historically, T'au was discovered millennia ago by the Adeptus Mechanicus' vessel, Land's Vision, long before the T'au attained spacefaring capabilities. The planet narrowly avoided Imperial conquest when a Warp Storm isolated it from the broader galaxy. During this isolation, the T'au rapidly advanced culturally and technologically, emerging as a sophisticated starfaring civilization after the Warp Storm dissipated in the 39th Millennium. The T'au Sept, originating from these early explorers, serves as a template for subsequent T'au colonies, influencing their military and administrative structures.

The warriors of T'au Sept are renowned for their strategic prowess, focusing on eliminating single targets with efficiency. They adhere strictly to their established combat doctrines, which have been adopted across T'au colonies. The cultural and military influence of T'au Sept resonates throughout the T'au Empire, embodying the disciplined and forward-thinking ethos that defines the T'au's approach to expansion and governance.

The Adeptus Arbites, in contrast, uphold the extensive and intricate Imperial Law of the Imperium of Man. Located on Terra, the Hall of Judgement houses millennia of legal precedent and rulings, guiding Arbites in their enforcement duties across human-settled worlds. The Imperium's legal system, rooted in religious reverence for the God-Emperor, mandates obedience and service from all humanity, with crimes against this divine order seen as blasphemous. The Arbites' role extends to quelling planetary unrest and sedition, ensuring Imperial stability through rigorous enforcement and judicial process.

The Inquisition, operating outside standard Imperial hierarchy, combats threats ranging from Chaos corruption to alien incursions. Divided between Puritan and Radical factions, Inquisitors interpret and enforce Imperial law with varying degrees of adherence to tradition or innovation. This complexity underscores the Imperium's authoritarian governance, where legal interpretation and enforcement are pivotal to maintaining order amidst myriad threats to human dominance in the galaxy.
43.name: T'au Homeworld

44.content:
The Imperator-class Titan stands as the pinnacle of Titan technology within the Imperium of Man, towering over its counterparts with unmatched size and devastating firepower. These colossal war machines are revered as walking fortresses, housing an array of armaments that eclipse those of smaller Titans like the Warmaster-class. Known for their role as Emperor-grade Titans, they are rarely seen on the battlefield due to the Adeptus Mechanicus' lost ability to produce them.

In contrast to their more specialized counterpart, the Warmonger-class, Imperator Titans serve as versatile assault platforms. Their design features a massive upper structure resembling a fortified cathedral, an iconic symbol of both awe-inspiring power and devotion to the Machine God. Despite their immense bulk which limits speed and agility, Imperator Titans compensate with an arsenal that includes arm-mounted primary weapons like Hellstorm Cannons and Plasma Annihilators, supported by an extensive array of secondary weapons and formidable Void Shields.

Emperor-grade Titans are not merely machines of war; they are considered avatars of the Machine God himself, embodying divine wrath against enemies of the Omnissiah. This symbolic significance is reflected in their ornate architecture and the religious reverence with which they are maintained by their crews. Deployed strategically as mobile fortresses or spearheading major offensives, Imperator Titans remain unrivaled in their capacity to unleash devastating barrages from a safe distance, making them critical assets in the Imperium's most crucial battles.

In conclusion, Imperator-class Titans epitomize the Imperium's technological might and religious zeal. Rare and revered, these god-engines stand as both symbols of awe and instruments of annihilation, ensuring that wherever they tread, the enemies of humanity face the inexorable wrath of the Machine God incarnate.
44.name: The Imperator-class

45.content:
Titans are massive robotic combat walkers fielded by the Titan Legions of the Adeptus Mechanicus' Collegia Titanica or the Dark Mechanicum. Originally referring to many types of large combat walkers used by different factions, the term "Titan" now only applies to Imperial and Chaos Titans, with the war engines of xenos races having their own designations. Titans are the most sacred and powerful ground units of the Imperium, with the ability to crush armies and devastate the battlefield. They range in size from around 15 meters tall for Scout Titans up to 150 meters tall for the immense Emperor Titans.
Titans are divided into different classes based on size and combat role. The smaller Scout Titans like Warhounds are fast and agile, used for reconaissance and infantry support. Battle Titans like Reavers and Warlords form the backbone of Titan Legions with a mix of firepower and durability. The gigantic Emperor Titans are the kings of the battlefield, with whole castles and cathedrals on their enormous frames, though they are very rare. Each Titan is given a unique High Gothic name and losing one is considered a tragic event mourned by its Forge World.
The weaponry carried by Titans is specialized for different combat roles, from targeting elite enemies and fortifications to wiping out legions of troops or providing devastating artillery support. Scout Titans wield relatively short-ranged weapons designed to destroy light vehicles and infantry swarms. Battle Titans and Emperor Titans mount much longer-ranged and more powerful weapons that can annihilate enemy Titans, superheavy tanks, and fortresses. Titans are also shielded by nigh-impenetrable armour and powerful void shields that can absorb massive amounts of destructive energy before failing. The presence of even a single Titan can turn the tide of a battle, and nothing inspires more awe and terror than the sight of these behemoths unleashing their apocalyptic fury.
45.name: Titans

46.content:
The Collegia Titanica is one of the oldest and most powerful arms of the Adeptus Mechanicus, operating the mighty Titans which have served Humanity since the Age of Strife. These towering god-engines played a pivotal role during the Great Crusade, carrying the light of Unification to countless worlds alongside the Space Marine Legions. The Titan Legions were organized into distinct Orders, each with its own unique culture and traditions, and collectively formed a politically influential entity within the nascent Imperium.
During the cataclysmic events of the Horus Heresy, the Titan Legions found themselves on opposing sides of the conflict. Many declared their allegiance to the Warmaster Horus, turning against their former allies and unleashing unimaginable destruction upon the Imperium. Bitter rivalries between certain Titan Legions were aggravated into outright hatred, leading to devastating clashes on numerous worlds such as Calth, Tallarn, and Beta-Garmon. The Siege of Terra saw the Traitor Titans of the Legio Mortis finally breach the walls of the Imperial Palace, though Horus' ultimate defeat forced them to flee into the Eye of Terror.
In the millennia following the Heresy, the Collegia Titanica continued to serve the Imperium, bringing its immense firepower to bear against various threats. The Loyalist Titan Orders, united under the reformed Adeptus Titanicus, remained vigilant, guarding the Imperium from Chaos incursions and xenos threats. They participated in major conflicts such as the Siege of Vraks, the Badab War, and the Third War for Armageddon, often playing decisive roles in these campaigns.
As the 41st Millennium drew to a close, the Collegia Titanica faced one of its greatest challenges during the 13th Black Crusade. The Titan Legions stationed near the Eye of Terror were called upon to defend the Fortress World of Cadia against the forces of Chaos, with many Legions committing their entire strength to this critical battle. The outcome of this monumental clash would determine the fate of the Imperium and the galaxy as a whole.
46.name: The Collegia Titanica

47.content:
The Tyranids are an extragalactic alien species that pose an existential threat to all life in the Milky Way Galaxy. They are a nomadic, predatory species that strip all biological matter from the planets they invade, leaving nothing but barren rocks in their wake. The Tyranids travel across the vast emptiness of space in gigantic, living starships known as Hive Ships, each home to countless lesser Tyranid organisms. They are drawn to the galaxy by the psychic beacon of the Astronomican, and their numberless swarms have already consumed countless worlds.
All Tyranids are connected by a psychic hive mind that allows them to communicate and coordinate instantly on a staggering scale. The largest Tyranid bioforms, called Synapse Creatures, serve as focal points for this Hive Mind, and through them, the swarm is controlled. The coming of a Tyranid Hive Fleet is preceded by a smothering psychic signal that envelops entire star systems and disrupts all forms of Warp travel and communication. This is known as the "Shadow in the Warp," and it heralds imminent invasion and horror.
Tyranid combat doctrine is based on overwhelming the enemy with sheer numbers and winning victories through attrition. Their armies are vast hordes of specialized organisms, each bioform playing a unique role in battle. Tyranid weapons and technology are entirely biological, living organisms that are lethal extensions of the creatures that wield them. On the battlefield, the Tyranids adapt quickly to enemy tactics, evolving new bioforms to overcome any resistance.
A Tyranid planetary invasion progresses through distinct stages, beginning with subtle infiltration by advanced organisms and culminating in total consumption of the planet's biomass. Vanguard drone ships and independent creatures like Genestealers and Lictors first scout out a target planet and gradually infest it. When a foothold has been established, a Hive Fleet arrives in-system and rains devastation upon the planet, initiating a two-pronged assault. On the ground, endless swarms of Tyranid warriors sweep across continents, leaving a carpet of dead in their wake. In the skies, winged creatures swarm in numbers large enough to blot out the sun. Capillary Towers burst from the planet's crust, siphoning biological matter to feed the swarm. The defenders of the planet must fight an all-out war of survival, for against this most implacable of foes there can be no surrender or retreat.
47.name: The Tyranids

48.content:
The Hive Mind represents the collective consciousness of the Tyranid species, a nearly omniscient psychic entity originating from outside the Milky Way Galaxy. It exerts total control over every Tyranid creature, directing their actions through a powerful mental grip. Central to this control are synapse creatures, like the Hive Tyrant, which act as conduits for the Hive Mind’s psychic commands. When these synapse creatures are killed, the control is disrupted, leaving lesser Tyranid bioforms to revert to basic animal instincts. On the battlefield, larger and more autonomous Tyranids, such as Hive Tyrants and Tyranid Warriors, telepathically channel the Hive Mind's influence to manage smaller bioforms, ensuring they act cohesively rather than succumbing to instinctive behaviors.

The complexity and power of the Hive Mind's psychic gestalt are such that it can drive most psykers insane or even kill them. Chief Librarian Tigurius of the Ultramarines is the only known Imperial agent to have interacted with the Hive Mind and retained his sanity, likely due to his exceptional predictive talents. His ability to understand the Hive Mind's intentions suggests a rare and profound connection, a feat otherwise considered achievable only by psykers of immense power, comparable to the Emperor of Mankind. This intense psychic presence also enables the Hive Mind to disrupt interstellar communications and Warp travel, a phenomenon known as the "Shadow in the Warp." This ability allows the Hive Mind to isolate targeted galaxies, preventing reinforcements and trapping inhabitants in a psychic shroud.

The Shadow in the Warp creates an atmosphere of terror and confusion on prey worlds, preventing calls for assistance and causing widespread despair. This psychic shroud penetrates the minds of nearby creatures, manifesting as a profound malaise, especially magnified in those with psychic potential, potentially leading to incurable psychosis. As a Hive Fleet approaches a target, entire populations often descend into madness even before any Tyranids land. This invasive psychic influence ensures the Hive Mind’s dominance, spreading fear and chaos that weaken resistance long before physical combat begins.
48.name: The Hive Mind

49.content:
Genestealer Cults are insidious organizations that thrive in the dark corners of the Imperium, secretly spreading their alien influence and undermining Mankind's realms. These cults are created and controlled by the Genestealer, a Tyranid organism capable of infecting hosts with its genetic material to create hybrids. The original Genestealer Patriarch begins the infection cycle, and as the cult grows, it psychically controls the brood. The infected hosts, or Contagii, return to their societies, compelled to reproduce and spread the Genestealer's DNA. Though Contagii mostly resemble their original species, they are mental slaves to the Patriarch's will.
As the infection spreads, the Genestealer hybrids become increasingly Human-like with each generation. The first generation hybrids are monstrous and alien, while the second generation is more sapient but still noticeably inhuman. By the third generation, the hybrids can pass for Human mutants, hiding their true nature from society. The fourth generation hybrids, or Primacii, are nearly indistinguishable from Humans and infiltrate positions of authority to advance the cult's agenda. Some of these fourth generation hybrids develop psychic powers, becoming the Magus or Primus of the cult.
The Genestealer Cult grows in secret, spreading throughout the host society and even to other worlds as subsequent generations breed and infect new victims. All the while, they are united and controlled by the Patriarch's Broodmind, a psychic gestalt consciousness. The hybrids are fiercely loyal to their cult and Patriarch, prioritizing the survival and propagation of their brood above all else.
Once the cult has grown strong enough, it will rise up in a violent insurrection, seeking to overthrow the rule of the Imperium on their host planet in the name of their Patriarch and vile Tyranid gods. They utilize a combination of subterfuge, underground organization, infiltration, and the psychic might of their leaders to prepare for this uprising. When the time is right, the cult will burst forth in a tide of violence, armed with stolen weapons and equipment, as well as their own twisted bioforms and hybrid monstrosities. If the cult successfully conquers the planet, it will ultimately be consumed by the Tyranid Hive Fleet drawn to the psychic signal of the Broodmind, but until that day, the cult fights with unbreakable devotion to its abhorrent masters.
49.name: Genestealer Cults

50.content:
The High Lords of Terra, collectively known as the High Twelve or the Senatorum Imperialis, form the highest governing body of the Imperium of Man. Tasked with interpreting the divine will of the Emperor of Mankind, they wield immense political power over the galaxy-spanning empire. Originally established during the Age of the Imperium, their authority evolved from the Emperor's decision to decentralize direct governance, entrusting mortal leaders with managing the Imperium's vast bureaucracy and administration.

Throughout history, the High Lords have been pivotal in guiding the Imperium's policies and decisions, impacting the lives of trillions across countless worlds. Their role as interpreters of the Emperor's will became especially crucial after the Emperor's internment upon the Golden Throne following the Horus Heresy. During this dark period, figures like Malcador the Sigillite and later Roboute Guilliman played instrumental roles in shaping the Senatorum Imperialis into its current form. Guilliman, upon his return during the Ultramar Campaign, undertook significant reforms, reconstituting the Senatorum Imperialis to better suit the Imperium's needs in the turbulent Era Indomitus.

The composition of the High Lords typically includes leaders from the most powerful adepta and institutions of the Imperium, such as the Adeptus Administratum, Adeptus Mechanicus, and the Inquisition. Each member represents not only their respective organization but also embodies centuries of tradition, alliances, and occasional power struggles. Over the millennia, the structure of the Senatorum Imperialis has seen changes, from adding seats for influential figures like the Ecclesiarch to weathering crises such as the Reign of Blood during the Age of Apostasy.

Roboute Guilliman's return marked a notable shift as he assumed the role of lord commander and Imperial Regent, consolidating executive authority in a single figure, albeit with the support and counsel of the High Lords. This centralization aimed to streamline decision-making in the face of galactic threats like the Great Rift and the Noctis Aeterna. Despite this, political tensions persist, as seen in disputes over territorial claims and autonomy rights, particularly concerning the Adeptus Mechanicus.

Thus, while the High Lords of Terra continue to interpret the Emperor's will and govern the Imperium with vast authority, their history reflects a complex interplay of institutional power, religious influence, and strategic leadership in an empire constantly besieged by external and internal threats.
50.name: The High Lords of Terra

51.content:
The Aeldari, once known as the Eldar, are an ancient and highly advanced humanoid species whose vast empire once spanned the galaxy. They were the undisputed masters of the stars, counting themselves as the most powerful race and pursuing their whims and desires without restraint. However, their overweening pride and fall into decadence ultimately led to a cataclysm of their own making. The psychic backlash of their hedonistic excesses coalesced in the Warp, birthing the Chaos God Slaanesh. The Fall of the Aeldari shattered their civilization, and the newborn deity consumed the souls of billions as it took its first breath. To escape this fate, the surviving Aeldari factions each pursued different paths to survival.
The Asuryani, or Craftworld Aeldari, fled on gigantic starships, adopting strict codes of behavior to keep their darker impulses in check. They rely on advanced psychocrystalline technology called Spirit Stones and Infinity Circuits to safeguard their souls after death. The Drukhari, also known as the Dark Eldar, retreated deep into the labyrinthine confines of the Webway, particularly the Dark City of Commorragh. They stave off Slaanesh's hunger by indulging in piracy, torture, and the suffering of others. The Exodites, who foresaw the coming fall, rejected the decadence of their kin and settled on remote worlds, living simpler, hardier lives more attuned to nature. The Harlequins, devotees of the Laughing God Cegorach, travel between the Aeldari factions as performers and storytellers, preserving their mythic history and culture.
In the 41st Millennium, the Aeldari find themselves beset by threats from all sides. The Imperium of Man has risen to preeminence in the galaxy, and its teeming armies often come into conflict with the dwindling Aeldari. The brutish Orks, given strength by the constant conflict, threaten to overrun the galaxy if left unchecked. The Tyranids from beyond the galactic rim devour all in their path, seeing the Aeldari worlds as a bounty of biomass. The Necrons, ancient foes of the Aeldari from before the Fall, arise from their hibernation to renew their war against all life. Worst of all, the coming of the Great Rift has spilled the forces of Chaos into realspace like never before, drowning the galaxy in conflict and corruption.
Amidst this age of unending war, a new Aeldari god has awakened. Ynnead, the Whispering God, offers salvation to all Aeldari, and a final end to the soul-hunger of Slaanesh. The Ynnari, followers of Ynnead's prophet Yvraine, seek to unite the fractured Aeldari factions and resurrect their race to its former glory. But the path ahead is dark and dangerous, and the future of the Aeldari remains uncertain in this era of woe and strife.
51.name: The Aeldari

52.content:
The Segmentum Obscurus, also known as the Segmentum Obscura, is a sprawling region of Imperial space situated to the galactic north of Terra. It is infamous for its proximity to the Eye of Terror, a colossal Warp rift and permanent Warp storm that serves as the primary stronghold for the chaotic forces of the galaxy. This region of the Imperium of Man has historically borne the brunt of assaults launched by Abaddon the Despoiler during his Black Crusades, particularly the 13th in 999.M41, which pushed Imperial forces to unprecedented levels of mobilization reminiscent of the Horus Heresy.

Following the cataclysmic events of the Great Rift's formation during the Era Indomitus, much of the Segmentum Obscurus now resides within the Imperium Nihilus, where the guiding light of the Astronomican struggles to penetrate. This has plunged the region into darkness and isolation, complicating communications and travel across its sectors and systems.

Key sectors within the Segmentum Obscurus include notable regions like Agripinaa, known for its industrial might and critical role in supplying military resources to Cadia; the Gothic Sector, which witnessed the infamous Gothic War and subsequent Chaos incursions; and the Calixis Sector, a hub of political intrigue and site of the Dark Heresy role-playing game, situated near the treacherous Halo Stars.

At the heart of the Segmentum Obscurus lies Cypra Mundi, where the Imperial Navy's Segmentum fleet headquarters commands operations and coordinates defenses against Chaos incursions. This system also serves as the central hub for Segmentum Command, overseeing military strategy and response across the Imperium's northern territories.

Despite its strategic importance and the valor of its defenders, the Segmentum Obscurus remains a region fraught with peril and beset by constant threats from the Eye of Terror and other chaotic influences. Its worlds, from heavily fortified bastions like Cadia to industrial powerhouses like Agripinaa, stand as bulwarks against the encroaching darkness that threatens to engulf the Imperium's northern frontiers.
52.name: The Segmentum Obscurus

53.content:
Exterminatus is the ultimate sanction wielded by the Imperium of Man, executed only in dire circumstances where a planet poses an existential threat to humanity across the galaxy. Initiated by the highest echelons of Imperial command—the Astra Militarum, Navis Imperialis, Adeptus Astartes, or the Imperial Inquisition—Exterminatus aims to eradicate all life and render a world uninhabitable. It is a measure of last resort, enacted when the cost of holding or reclaiming a planet for the Emperor exceeds acceptable limits, or when the risk of chaos, mutation, or heresy spreading beyond containment becomes intolerable.

The methods employed in Exterminatus are devastating and varied. Orbital bombardment, the simplest and most direct approach, utilizes the overwhelming firepower of Imperial warships to rain down destruction ranging from precision strikes to cataclysmic thermonuclear blasts. Virus bombs, engineered to unleash the Life-Eater Virus, swiftly reduce planetary life to a bio-chemical sludge, often igniting the atmosphere into a planet-wide firestorm to ensure complete eradication. Cyclonic torpedoes, another grim tool, induce thermonuclear reactions or plasma bombardments that obliterate a planet's biosphere, leaving behind a lifeless husk.

These actions are not taken lightly; the decision to enact Exterminatus undergoes rigorous scrutiny within the Imperium. Inquisitors wield the authority to order Exterminatus autonomously, while Chapter Masters of the Adeptus Astartes may also authorize such drastic measures when deemed necessary. The repercussions of these decisions are profound, with the potential loss of billions of lives weighed against the preservation of the Imperium itself. Instances of Exterminatus on strategically vital worlds are exceedingly rare, highlighting its role as a measure reserved for the gravest threats to human survival.

Rare variants of Exterminatus, like two-stage cyclonic torpedoes used against biologically void or Necron-infested worlds, further underscore the diversity and severity of these methods. Each instance marks a grim testament to the Imperium's unyielding resolve and readiness to make sacrificial decisions in the name of humanity's survival. Though controversial and morally fraught, Exterminatus remains a chilling reminder of the Imperium's uncompromising stance against threats that could jeopardize its vast dominion spanning the galaxy.
53.name: Exterminatus

54.content:
The Segmentum Pacificus, located to the galactic west of Terra, is a notable region of Imperial space. The headquarters of the Imperial Navy fleet in this segmentum is on Hydraphur, which also serves as the segmentum fortress.

The segmentum gained fame through Lord Commander Solar Macharius's campaign, where he conquered a thousand worlds. It was also a hub during the Plague of Unbelief in the 36th Millennium, when Apostate Cardinal Bucharis attempted to create his own empire. In the 41st Millennium, the Sabbat Worlds Crusade occurred here, aiming to reclaim the sector from Chaos forces.

The Veiled Region lies to the galactic south of the Segmentum Pacificus. This unmapped frontier is characterized by dense nebulae, newborn stars, and intense stellar radiation. It houses Ork corsairs, xenos mercenaries, a primitive alien race, and the feared Necrons. The Soul Drinkers, a Renegade Space Marine Chapter, once sought refuge here.

The Laanah Rifts, located in the northwestern Segmentum Pacificus, were dominated by aliens and heretics until the Belrath Crusade in 182.M38 brought much of the area under Imperial control, leading to the creation of the Laanah Sector.

Notable sectors include the Chiros Sector, a turbulent frontier plagued by xenos incursions and Chaos rebellions, and the Sabbat Worlds Sector, a group of over 100 star systems along the rimward edge of the Segmentum. This region, named after Saint Sabbat who led its initial Imperial colonization, faced severe Chaos invasions in the 41st Millennium. The Imperium's forces are engaged in an ongoing crusade to reclaim it.

Notable worlds in the Segmentum Pacificus include Constantinium, known for its rebellions; Hydraphur, the Imperial Navy Battlefleet Pacificus headquarters; Macharia, the shrine world of Saint Macharius; Oghram, an early victim of the Tyranid Hive Fleet Leviathan; Tanith, home of the Tanith First and Only regiment, destroyed by Chaos; and Verghast, where Vervunhive fell to Chaos during the Sabbat Worlds Crusade.

The Halo Zone, at the galaxy's edge, contains ancient stars and remains largely unexplored due to its distance from the Astronomican, making navigation extremely hazardous. This region's mystery and danger have discouraged many from venturing into its depths.
54.name: The Segmentum Pacificus

55.content:
The Cadian Gate is an area of calm space leading into and out of the massive Warp rift called the Eye of Terror. It is located to the galactic southeast of the Eye in the Segmentum Obscurus, and is the only predictably stable way out of that maelstrom of Warp energy.

It is therefore a site of frequent raids by the forces of Chaos seeking to break through the Imperial defences in the region so that they can invade the larger Imperium of Man.

Several Black Crusades have emerged from the Cadian Gate, including the most recent campaign, the 13th Black Crusade, led by the Chaos Lord Abaddon the Despoiler. This led to its continuous monitoring by the Imperium and the stationing of several forces of the Astra Militarum in the closest star system, the Cadian System.

However, Abaddon succeeded in penetrating the Cadian Gate when Cadia itself was swallowed by the Warp following the successful conclusion of the 13th Black Crusade and the destruction of the world's Cadian Pylons after the Despoiler used the disabled Blackstone Fortress Will of Eternity as a kinetic impactor.
55.name: The Cadian Gate

56.content:
A Blackstone Fortress, known to the Aeldari as a Talisman of Vaul, is a massive, alien-constructed starfort and Warp-based strategic weapon employed by both the Imperium of Man and the forces of Chaos during their more recent conflicts.

According to some Imperial scholars, the Blackstone Fortresses were constructed and first used during the war between the Old Ones and the Necrons remembered in Aeldari legend as the War in Heaven. To capitalise on the Necrons' and their C'tan masters' vulnerability to Warp-based attacks during the War in Heaven, the fortresses were equipped with a Warp Cannon that could create a devastating rip in the fabric of realspace that would unleash an eruption of psychic energy from the Immaterium powerful enough to destroy entire star systems. This power can be linked with that of the other fortresses to create an even more powerful beam, as became clear when Abaddon the Despoiler used two of the fortresses to destroy the planet Fularis II, and three to cause the Tarantis star to go supernova during the Gothic War.
56.name: Blackstone Fortress

57.content:
Abaddon the Despoiler, also known as Ezekyle Abaddon, holds the title of Warmaster of the Imperium Nihilus and is revered as the foremost champion of Chaos Undivided in the galaxy. He commands the Black Legion of Chaos Space Marines, speculated to be a genetic descendant of the infamous Warmaster Horus, once his favored son and first captain of the Sons of Horus Legion.

Abaddon's notoriety stems from his leadership in the Black Crusades, massive Chaos offensives from the Eye of Terror against the Imperium. These campaigns form part of his strategic "Crimson Path," aimed at reaching Terra itself, culminating in the Great Rift's creation during the 13th Black Crusade. This catastrophic event divided the galaxy and ushered in the Noctis Aeterna and Era Indomitus.

Initially rising to prominence as Horus's first captain during the Great Crusade, Abaddon's loyalty shifted with Horus's rebellion against the Emperor during the Horus Heresy. After Horus's death, Abaddon inherited his mantle, leading the renamed Sons of Horus Legion across pivotal battles like Isstvan III, Isstvan V, and Terra. His grief and anger at Horus's demise fueled a relentless pursuit of vengeance against the Imperium.

Following the Heresy, Abaddon transformed the Sons of Horus into the fearsome Black Legion and initiated the infamous 1st Black Crusade. He forged dark alliances with the Chaos Gods, notably recovering the Daemon Sword Drach'nyen, enhancing his unstoppable reputation. Subsequent Black Crusades, now totaling twelve, furthered his enigmatic goals, consolidating his power and unraveling the Imperium's defenses.

Abaddon's enduring ambition is to succeed where Horus failed: breaching the Imperial Palace, dethroning the Emperor from the Golden Throne, and reshaping the galaxy in Chaos's image. His influence spans millennia, gradually eroding the barriers between realspace and the Warp, leaving an indelible mark on galactic history.

In the Imperium, Abaddon's name evokes dread and serves as a reminder of Chaos's relentless threat. His determination to unite the Traitor Legions and fulfill ancient prophecies continues to drive him, promising a future where the Ruinous Powers reign supreme.

Despite facing numerous setbacks and betrayals, Abaddon remains resolute, driven by an unquenchable thirst for vengeance and dominion. His legacy as the Warmaster of Chaos is intertwined with the galaxy's darkest epochs, shaping its fate in ways few can comprehend or oppose.
57.name: Abaddon the Despoiler

58.content:
Chaos Titans are monstrous war machines transformed by the corrupting influence of Chaos, merging machine and daemon into horrifying amalgamations. Unlike their Imperial counterparts, the crews of these Titans often fuse with their machines, becoming indistinguishable from them. During the Horus Heresy, many Titan Legions turned to Chaos, forming the Dark Mechanicum. Over millennia, more Legions succumbed to corruption, aligning themselves with one of the four Ruinous Powers of Chaos. Slaanesh Chaos Titans, for instance, utilize their incredible speed and the Glamour of Slaanesh, a shimmering aura that confounds enemy targeting systems. These Titans are animated by bound daemons and employ devastating weaponry like Psi-Pulse generators and Tormentor Cannons to crush their foes.

The corruption and transformation of these Titans vary based on their alignment with specific Chaos Gods. For example, the Banelord-class Titan, dedicated to Khorne, features brutal modifications such as a tail cannon and specialized weapons like the Havoc Missile Rack. Other classes like the Plaguelord, Painlord, and Warplord Titans are dedicated to Nurgle, Slaanesh, and Tzeentch respectively, each reflecting their patron god's unique traits. The Feral-class Titans, once Imperial Warhound-class Titans, have been reclassified due to their deep corruption and millennia of service to Chaos. These Titans' machine spirits and crews are fully possessed, serving the will of Chaos eternally. The Ravager-class Titans, once Reaver-class Titans, have undergone similar transformations, becoming relics of terror from the Horus Heresy, now dedicated to perpetual warfare under Chaos.

Among the mightiest of these corrupted war machines are the Chaos Emperor Titans, such as the infamous Imperator-class Dies Irae and Abominatus, fused with Greater Daemons to become nearly unstoppable. These Titans are rarely deployed, reserved for the most crucial battles where Chaos is willing to pay any price for victory. Their transformation into Chaos Titans involves intricate and malevolent rituals, binding daemons to their forms and imbuing them with malevolent power. Such Titans stand as towering embodiments of the Chaos Gods' might, revered by lesser beings and feared by their enemies. With their horrific capabilities and daemonic enhancements, Chaos Titans are unparalleled instruments of destruction in the service of the Ruinous Powers.
58.name: Chaos Titans

59.content:
The Death Korps of Krieg is the name given to all of the Astra Militarum regiments that originate from the devastated, post-nuclear Death World of Krieg in the Segmentum Tempestus.

Krieg was the site of a rebellion against the Imperium of Man over 1,500 standard years ago in the 40th Millennium and was bombarded with nuclear weapons followed by five hundred Terran years of grinding warfare to purge the heretical rebels.

After all those years of nuclear destruction and bitter trench warfare, Krieg was reduced to a scorched, radioactive husk of a world composed of dust and mud whose surviving people were forced to retreat into underground hive cities to survive the toxic planetary environment.

The Death Korps of Krieg is a siege specialist Militarum Regimento of the Astra Militarum and the regiments raised on Krieg seek to repent for their former treachery against the Emperor by displaying a disturbing disregard for their own lives in combat. Death Korps troops excel at wars of attrition and defensive combat in particular.

In 433.M40, the once-loyal Imperial world of Krieg declared independence and renounced the glory of the God-Emperor. At that moment, the world was changed forever. Colonel Jurten, commander of the 83rd Krieg Regiment of the Astra Militarum, gathered to him all those still loyal to the Imperium, and struck back against the rebellion, choosing to unleash the horror of atomic bombardment upon those who had forsaken the Emperor.

After five hundred standard years of atomic fire, continent-spanning trench warfare, and thunderous artillery barrages, the attempted secession of Krieg was halted, but at great cost: Krieg had become a blasted, irradiated wasteland, barely inhabitable by Humans. The remaining population was forced to exist in the subterranean bunkers and tunnels that had spread across the planet during the war, and found that they could not walk upon the surface without protective equipment.

Seeking to atone for the betrayal their world's government had committed, and with no other resources left to offer up in the Imperial Tithe, the people of Krieg set about providing the only thing they had left -- manpower. Hardened by generations of war in an atomic wasteland, the Krieg people were already well-prepared to be sent out into the galaxy as Imperial Guardsmen.

Trained amongst the irradiated ruins of long-dead cities, equipped for the most hostile environments, and raised on sermons of self-sacrifice and penitence, the Krieg regiments have commonly been deployed -- often at their own request -- to some of the deadliest warzones, from the toxic ash wastes that surround many hive cities, to brutal wars of attrition and years-long sieges
59.name: The Death Korps

60.content:
The Machine God, also known as the Omnissiah or Deus Mechanicus, is the supernatural entity worshipped by the tech-priests and other servants of the Adeptus Mechanicus as the embodiment and bestower of all knowledge and technology in the universe.

For many in the Imperium of Man, this belief conflicts with the orthodox theology of the Imperial Cult where the only god of Humanity is the Emperor of Mankind.

But since the Adeptus Mechanicus is vital to the survival of the Imperium, conflict over this issue is often avoided by the Mechanicus' willing conflation in its theology of the Machine God's avatar in the physical world, the so-called "Omnissiah," with the Emperor Himself.

This compromise truly satisfies neither believers in the Cult Mechanicus or the Imperial Cult, but it keeps the peace between the two faiths and the wider Imperium functioning
60.name: Omnissiah

61.content:
The Dark Mechanicum, formerly part of the loyal Adeptus Mechanicus, betrayed their allegiance during the Horus Heresy, siding with Warmaster Horus and Chaos. This sect, known for its tech-heresy, includes renegade Tech-priests, Collegia Titanica members, and Chaos Knights from the Mechanicum. They worship Chaos and seek forbidden knowledge.

After the Horus Heresy, the Dark Mechanicum fled to the Eye of Terror and other remote corners of the galaxy. They were driven from Mars by loyalist forces of the Adeptus Mechanicus, sparking a brutal civil war known as the Schism of Mars.

Led by Fabricator-General Kelbor-Hal, the Dark Mechanicum collaborated with Horus to build the Furious Abyss, a mighty battleship aimed at the destruction of the Ultramarines. Their arsenal included dark and forbidden technologies corrupted by Chaos, such as scrap code and techno-viral weaponry.

During the Heresy, they allied with traitor forces, deploying their powerful Titan Legions and Knight houses against loyalist factions. Many Forge Worlds joined their cause, drawn by promises of autonomy and freedom from Imperial restrictions on research and AI.

In the current era, the Dark Mechanicum resides within the Eye of Terror, servicing Chaos forces with their extensive knowledge of forbidden technologies. They revere Chaos Gods as patrons, contrasting sharply with their Adeptus Mechanicus counterparts who follow the Omnissiah.

Beyond the Eye of Terror, some Dark Mechanicum factions inhabit regions like the Calixis Sector, evading Imperial pursuit while practicing their dark arts. They are hunted relentlessly by the Inquisition and viewed as dangerous heretics by the Adeptus Mechanicus.
61.name: The Dark Mechanicum

62.content:
Spice was the name for a type of illicit substance or substances in demand throughout the galaxy. Spice was mined at the spice mines of Kessel, where slaves such as captured Wookiees were worked to death turning mined medicinal spice mineral into a recreational drug. Spice mines could be found in several other planetary systems throughout the galaxy, including those of Ryloth and Naboo. One variation of the narcotic known as ryll was mined on the planet Ryloth and had both scientific and recreational applications. Sansanna spice was a type of spice that could be found throughout the galaxy.

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Spice
62.name: Spice

63.content:
A planet, often called a world, was a celestial body that was in orbit around a star, was neither a binary star nor a moon, and had cleared out the area around its orbit as it formed by causing all other smaller bodies in its orbit to accrete with it. As a consequence, it would not share its orbital region with any other bodies of significant size, except for moons or those collected later under its gravitational influence. 

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Planet/Legends
63.name: Planet

64.content:
Naboo (pronounced /nə'bu/) was a planet that was the sector capital of the Chommell sector in the Mid Rim, near the border with the Outer Rim Territories. The planet had an unusual plasma core, and its surface was a largely unspoiled world with large plains, swamps and seas.

The Gungans were an amphibian species native to Naboo. The planet was also home to Human colonists from Grizmallt who called themselves the Naboo. In late galactic history, Naboo was mostly known as the homeworld of notable historical figures who played major roles in the downfall of the Galactic Republic and the rise of the Galactic Empire, namely Padmé Amidala, Emperor Palpatine and Jar Jar Binks. 

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Naboo/Legends
64.name: Naboo

65.content:
Coruscant (pronounced /'kɔɹəsɑnt/), also known as Jewel of the Core Worlds, or Imperial Center during the rule of the Galactic Empire, was an ecumenopolis—a city-covered planet, collectively known as Imperial City— in the Coruscant system of the Core Worlds. Though debated by historians, it was generally believed that Coruscant was the original homeworld of humanity. Coruscant was at one point also historically the home of the ancient Taung and Zhell. Noted for its cosmopolitan culture and towering skyscrapers, Coruscant's population consisted of trillions of citizens hailing from a vast array of both humanoid and alien species. In addition, Coruscant's strategic location at the end of several major trade routes enabled it to grow in power and influence, causing the city-planet to surpass its early rivals and become the hub of galactic culture, education, finance, fine arts, politics and technology. It was the location of several major landmarks, including the Jedi Temple, Monument Plaza, and the Senate Building. 
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Coruscant
65.name: Coruscant

66.content:
Species were unique lifeforms. They were generally divided into three classifications based on their level of sentience: sentient, semi-sentient, and non-sentient. There were over 20 million sentient species known to the galaxy. Sentient species were sometimes erroneously referred to as races, which more accurately referred to groups or subspecies within a species.
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Species/Legends
66.name: Species

67.content:
The Haven-class medical station, also known as the Republic medical station or the Republic medical base, was a model of space station manufactured by VenteX Construction Yards used by the Galactic Republic as a space-bound medcenter during the Clone Wars. The Kaliida Shoals Medical Center, located in the Ryndellia system, was a Haven-class medical station, as were the Ord Cestus medical station and Felucia Medical Station HCTFF2. The stations were designed so that from above, they looked like the Republic crest.
Haven-class medical stations were medical space stations manufactured by VenteX Construction Yards built around a long central shaft, which comprised the longest axis of the station. The cylindrical central hub had eight equidistant protrusions, which included docking areas for starships such as Venator-class Star Destroyers and Pelta-class frigates. From above, the station's shape resembled the Republic crest. The stations could carry a maximum of 80,000 patients at any one time.
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Haven-class_medical_station
67.name: Haven-class Medical Station

68.content:
A death stick was a highly addictive illicit substance readily found in the underworld of Coruscant and other locales across the galaxy. Delivered inside luminescent sticks, they were a favorite among desperate addicts and thrill-seekers.[2] Death sticks were created from distilled and refined ixetal cilona, made from the balo mushrooms found on the planet Balosar.

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Death_stick
68.name: Death stick

69.content:
From space, the planet of Hoth looked like a pale blue orb due to its dense snow and ice covering. Five planets existed between Hoth and its sun, while an asteroid belt surrounded the planet with meteors occasionally striking the surface. Most of its surface was covered with glaciers and frozen ice plains. Another third of the planet was covered by oceans. The temperature, although always frigid, was known to drop to -60°C come nightfall. Although devoid of intelligent life, Hoth was home to fifteen subspecies of tauntauns, which were commonly used by Rebels as a means of transport, and which Han Solo cut open to use as shelter to keep Luke Skywalker and himself warm during a snowstorm. It was also home to a species of towering predators known as wampas. During his stay on Hoth, Skywalker was captured by a wampa and was hung upside down in the wampa's cave, waiting to be eaten. Using the power of the Force, Skywalker managed to get his hands on his lightsaber and cut himself down from the roof and sever the wampa's right arm. The planet also had a number of "crystalline geysers."

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Hoth
69.name: Hoth

70.content:
Tython was a terrestrial planet located in Deep Core's Tython system that played a pivotal role in the history of the Jedi Order. A verdant world that was incredibly rich in the Force, Tython was eventually abandoned when the ever-changing hyperlanes in the region drifted away from the planet and became shrouded in myth. The Martyrium of Frozen Tears was built by Jedi there, and some Jedi scholars made the case that Tython was the site of the Jedi Order's first temple. During the Galactic Civil War, Doctor Chelli Lona Aphra led the Imperial commander Darth Vader to Tython's Meridional Ice Cap to mislead him as to the location of the Rebel Alliance's main base, which was actually on the Outer Rim planet Hoth. 
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Tython
70.name: Tython

71.content:
Alderaan, located in the Core Worlds, was a terrestrial planet covered with mountains. During the waning decades of the Galactic Republic, it was ruled by Queen Breha Organa and represented in the Galactic Senate by her husband, Senator Bail Prestor Organa. Alderaan was regarded for its natural beauty, its tranquility, and the sophistication of its arts and culture.

Following the rise of Sheev Palpatine's Galactic Empire, Alderaan played a pivotal role in the establishment of the Rebel Alliance, a movement that sought to restore the Old Republic's values, and was one of its earliest supporters. Because of its ties with the Alliance, the planet was destroyed when Grand Moff Wilhuff Tarkin decided to test the superlaser of the Death Star, a moon-sized battle station developed by the Empire, at full strength. Among the few survivors of that disaster was Princess Leia Organa, adopted daughter of Bail and Breha Organa and heiress to the royal house of Alderaan. 

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Alderaan
71.name: Alderaan

72.content:
Jakku was a remote desert planet located in the Jakku system, within the Western Reaches of the galaxy's Inner Rim and was the homeworld of the Teedo and Uthuthma species. Though considered by many within the galaxy to be distant and relatively worthless, Jakku was the site of important events that would shape galactic history. In 5 ABY, Jakku was the site of the pivotal Battle of Jakku, which ended the Galactic Civil War in favour of the New Republic and the collapse of the Galactic Empire. 
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Jakku
72.name: Jakku

73.content:
Nal Hutta, known also as just Hutta was a ringed planet nestled in the depths of Hutt Space. It was a mist-covered swamp world with a hot, humid and fetid climate maintained by thick swampy rain that fell almost perpetually. The world was a hotbed of life and its environment was fairly representative of the sentient Hutt species that inhabited the world.[14] The influence of the Hutts made the world an important location. The planet's surface was covered with numerous bogs with what little solid land there was claimed by the Hutts and used to support their homes.

The Hutts built only a handful of spaceports on the surface of Nal Hutta in order to connect their towns, settlements, and palaces, as the planet received few visitors due to most business with offworlders being conducted on the planet's largest moon, Nar Shaddaa. The foremost of these spaceports was the planet's capital city, Bilbousa, a sprawling mess covered in arching roots that spread out from looming bulbous pods. Within sight of the city was the Palace of Gardulla Besadii the Elder, one of the largest buildings on Nal Hutta, which served as the occasional headquarters of the Grand Hutt Council, the ruling body that both worked and led the Hutt Clan. Under the Hutt's control, the planet shared a reputation with Nar Shaddaa for being polluted and dangerous, but played a leading role in the galaxy's shadow economy.

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Nal_Hutta
73.name: Nal Hutta

74.content:
Tatooine was a sparsely inhabited circumbinary desert planet located in the galaxy's Outer Rim Territories. Part of a binary star system, the planet orbited two scorching suns, resulting in the world lacking the necessary surface water to sustain large populations. As a result, many residents of the planet instead drew water from the atmosphere via moisture farms. The planet also had little surface vegetation. It was the homeworld to the native Jawa and Tusken Raider species and of Anakin and Luke Skywalker, who would go on to shape galactic history.

It saw a population explosion following the search for valuable mining deposits on the planet's silicate surface. Finding the ore to have undesirable metallurgical properties, mining firms left the planet en masse, leaving behind valuable equipment, most notably large sandcrawlers, which were later used by the Jawa population. The planet then became a haven for smugglers and criminal activity, and fell under the influence of the Hutt Clan while scattered, isolated settlements of hard-working inhabitants endured.

Generally ignored by the galaxy at large, Tatooine gained the notice of the Galactic Empire during the Galactic Civil War when an escape pod carrying two droids in possession of top-secret information landed on the sandy Outer Rim world. The Empire went on to establish a heavier presence on the planet, forging a tenuous relationship with Jabba Desilijic Tiure of the Hutt Clan. Open conflict soon broke out between the Empire and a Rebel Alliance cell on Tatooine that culminated in a battle that left the Empire's hold on the world significantly weakened.

Following the death of Jabba and the withdrawal of Imperial forces after the Battle of Endor, an enormous power vacuum occurred on the world, with numerous crime syndicates like the Red Key Raiders attempting to build legitimacy as mining companies. Eventually, former bounty hunter Boba Fett returned and took over Jabba's former territory. Coming into conflict with both the Hutt Clan and the Pyke Syndicate, the new Daimyo was pulled into a gang war that threatened the future of Tatooine. With help from the Mandalorian Din Djarin, Fett rallied the denziens of the settlements Mos Espa and Freetown to push back against the invaders, ushering in a new era of respect between the people of the planet. 

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Tatooine
74.name: Tatooine

75.content:
Endor, designated IX3244-A, also known as the Forest Moon of Endor or the Sanctuary Moon, was a small forested moon that was the ninth moon that orbited the Outer Rim planet of the same name. It was the homeworld of the sentient Dulok, Ewok, and Yuzzum species, as well as the Wistie and semi-sentient Gorax races. 
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Endor
75.name: Endor

76.content:
Mustafar was a small planet located in the Mustafar system, within the Atravis sector of the galaxy's Outer Rim Territories. Once a garden world nourished by the Bright Star artifact, its orbit was shifted when Lady Corvax unleashed the energies of the Bright Star in an attempt to return her husband to life. The resulting gravimetric duel between the gas giants Jestefad and Lefrani over Mustafar heated the planet's core, transforming the lush world into an imbalanced volcanic hellscape. Adapting to life on their devastated homeworld, the arthropodal Mustafarians evolved into two distinct subspecies that cooperated to ensure their continued survival. Legends of Corvax's search for immortality brought the ancient Sith to Mustafar, seeking the same secrets of eternal life. There, they built a temple over a locus in the dark side of the Force, above the buried ruins of Corvax Fortress. 
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Mustafar
76.name: Mustafar

77.content:
Mandalore, also known as Mand'alor, was a planet located in the Outer Rim Territories. It was the homeworld of the Mandalorians, a fearsome warrior clan-based people, and the indigenous Alamite species. The Mandalorians once fought the Jedi and raided their temple during the fall of the Old Republic. Wearing distinctive armor that was often made from beskar, they were feared throughout the galaxy, and once had political influence over two thousand other star systems. 
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Mandalore
77.name: Mandalore

78.content:
The Coruscant Underworld, also called the Lower Coruscant, lower levels or undercity, were the levels underneath the surface structures of the planet Coruscant. These very first levels of Coruscant were constructed in 100,000 BBY and eventually rose from the soil into a world-spanning city. The underworld was a haven for bounty hunters, pirates, and criminal gangs, but also harbored war refugees and poor immigrants trying to make a pitiful living. Influential crime families operated in the lower levels of Coruscant, which were patrolled by the underworld police division of the Coruscant Security Force. Devoid of all sunlight, the lower levels were left in a perpetual state of darkness illuminated only by artificial lights for thousands of years. The underworld was polluted and infested with pests and dangerous escaped pets. The very lowest levels of the city were rumored to hold ancient secrets.

Skyscrapers towered above the highest level on Coruscant, Level 5127, on which lay the Galactic City, but under the surface structures the levels of Coruscant descended down all the way to Level 1, which was deemed uninhabitable. Undercity dwellers often had to breathe toxic fumes from millennia of urbanization, while wealthy citizens in the upper levels had access to rich and filtered air. The various levels of Coruscant were accessible by huge portals that also served as ventilation shafts.

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Coruscant_Underworld
78.name: Coruscant Underworld

79.content:
CoCo Town, also known as the Collective Commerce District or more simply as the Coco District, was a dilapidated industrial area of the planet Coruscant. It was also the site of Dex's Diner, a local eatery owned by Dexter Jettster during the Republic Era. Hard-working laborers visited CoCo Town to congregate at the diner.

During the Galactic Civil War, the Galactic Empire and the New Republic fought for control of the region. Many orphans from the area formed the Anklebiter Brigade, and fought alongside the rebels, sabotaging the Empire wherever possible

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/CoCo_Town
79.name: CoCo Town

80.content:
The Imperial Palace, also known as the Emperor's palace and known formerly as the Jedi Grand Temple, the Coruscant temple or simply the Jedi Temple, was the official residence of the Dark Lord of the Sith and Galactic Emperor Darth Sidious located in the Palace Court of the Federal District of Imperial City on Coruscant, the capital planet of the Galactic Empire during the Imperial Era. Though purged of its Jedi origins, the Palace retained its ziggurat form as well as its distinctive crown of four Council Towers and the central Palace spire that contained the Emperor's throne room.

Built as a Jedi temple by the Four Masters millennia before Sidious' rise to power, the Temple stood on the foundations of the Shrine in the Depths, serving as the home of the Jedi Order throughout the Republic Era. Over the centuries it was rebuilt and expanded several times. In addition to its role as the central hub of all Jedi activities throughout the galaxy, the Temple functioned as a monastery for Jedi Knights and Jedi Masters as well as a school for the training of Padawans and initiates. The Temple contained several key areas such as the Holocron Vault, which housed the Order's closely guarded secrets; the Jedi Archives, the largest repository of information; and the Jedi Council Chamber, where the ruling Jedi High Council convened to discuss galactic events and determine the will of the Force.

As leaders of the Grand Army of the Republic, the Jedi coordinated the war effort from the Temple on Coruscant during the Clone Wars between the Galactic Republic and the Confederacy of Independent Systems. Despite the Temple's security, it was infiltrated by the bounty hunter Cad Bane who stole a holocron at the behest of the Sith Lord Darth Sidious. In 19 BBY, the Temple was damaged by a bombing attack masterminded by Padawan Barriss Offee. Following the terrorist attack, the Jedi attempted to remove Palpatine as Supreme Chancellor upon learning of his secret identity as Darth Sidious. As a result, the 501st Legion marched on the Temple under the command of Sidious' Sith apprentice Darth Vader. Labeled as traitors under Order 66, the Jedi were attacked by clone troopers in the Temple and across the galaxy, marking the start of the Great Jedi Purge. With the Sith restored to power, the Jedi Temple became the Imperial Palace.

The Emperor's death at the Battle of Endor in 4 ABY prompted the citizens of Coruscant to celebrate in the streets of Monument Plaza while Grand Vizier Mas Amedda and his supporters barricaded themselves in the Palace. Around the same time, the Jedi Knight Luke Skywalker recovered fragments of the Great Tree that once stood in the heart of the Jedi Temple. In the final days of the Galactic Civil War, Amedda was placed under virtual house arrest in the Palace by soldiers who were loyal to Fleet Admiral Gallius Rax, the self-proclaimed Counselor to the Empire. He later escaped from the Palace with the help of a gaggle of children by the time of the Battle of Jakku in 5 ABY. 

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Imperial_Palace
80.name: Imperial Palace

81.content:
The Federal District, also known as the Senate District, Executive District, Legislative District, Military District, and colloquially referred to as the Core of Coruscant or Core Square, was the central government district on the planet Coruscant. It was the location of the Imperial Senate Building, the Avenue of the Core Founders, the Imperial Executive Building, and the Jedi Temple which, after proclamation of the New Order, was rechristened as the Imperial Palace. Other notable locations included 500 Republica, the headquarters of the Naval Intelligence Agency, and the COMPNOR arcology, which contained the central offices of the Imperial Security Bureau.

During the Clone Wars, the Confederacy of Independent Systems disabled the central power distribution grid of Coruscant, causing a power outage in the Federal District. The district was also damaged by a Zillo Beast that had been captured on Malastare and taken to the galactic capital. After the Galactic Republic became the Galactic Empire, the Jedi Order's temple became the palace of Galactic Emperor Sheev Palpatine. Following Emperor Palpatine's death in the Battle of Endor, the Empire fought to remain in control of the Federal District during a civil war between the Imperial government and the Coruscanti that supported the New Republic. 

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Federal_District
81.name: Federal District

82.content:
Humans, taxonomically referred to as Homo sapiens, were the galaxy's most numerous and politically dominant sentient species with millions of major and minor colonies galaxywide. Believed to have originated on the galactic capital of Coruscant, they could be found anywhere, engaged in many different pursuits: spacers, mercenaries, smugglers, merchants, soldiers, assassins, farmers, crime lords, laborers, slaves, slavers, and many others, including Jedi and Sith. Since Humans were the most common sentient species, they were often considered to be a standard or average to which the biology, psychology, and culture of other species were compared. 
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Human/Legends#Physical_diversity
82.name: Human

83.content:
The Wookiees, whose name for themselves translated to the People of the Trees, were a species of tall, hairy humanoids that were inhabitants of the planet Kashyyyk. One of the most noteworthy members of the species was Chewbacca, Han Solo's best friend and co-pilot; who played a vital role in the Galactic Civil War and afterwards. A race of arboreal mammals, the Wookiees lived in treehouses nestled in the canopy of the towering wroshyr trees. Despite their fearsome appearance, they were usually gentle, although they were prone to devastating fits of rage when provoked. 
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Wookiee/Legends
83.name: Wookiee

84.content:
Ewoks were a diminutive primitive species of furry bipeds native to the forest moon of Endor. They were most notable for helping the Rebel Alliance defeat the forces of the Galactic Empire at the Battle of Endor, allowing the shield generator there to be destroyed, and in turn, the DS-2 Death Star II Mobile Battle Station.

Ewoks were individuals that stood about one meter tall. They used spears, slings, and knives as weapons; they also used hang gliders as vehicles. Although skilled in forest survival and the construction of primitive technology, the Ewoks had yet to progress past stone-level technology when discovered by the Empire. They were quick learners, however, when exposed to advanced technology with simple mechanical processes and concepts. 

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Ewok
84.name: Ewok

85.content:
Cereans were a sophisticated and cultured humanoid mammalian species hailing from the planet Cerea in the Mid Rim. They were famed for their extraordinary thinking abilities, made possible by large binary brains housed in tall tapering heads, enabling them to focus on many things at the same time. Aside from this unique feature, Cereans were physically similar to Humans, although they each possessed two hearts, which supplied extra blood circulation to support their brains.

Cereans were often found among the ranks of the Jedi Knights, but due to the species' low birth rates, Cerean Jedi were exempt from the Order's vow of non-attachment.[5] One such Jedi, Ki-Adi-Mundi, served on the Jedi High Council during and prior to the outbreak of the Clone Wars. 

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Cerean/Legends
85.name: Cerean

86.content:
Sullustans were a species of Near-Humans from Sullust. As skilled pilots and navigators, Sullustans were common a sight for spacers and at busy spaceports. The Sullustans played an important role in the Galactic Civil War and were charter members of the New Republic. Notable members of the species include Nien Nunb, Ten Numb and Dllr Nep. 
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Sullustan/Legends
86.name: Sullustan

87.content:
Jawas were a sentient species of meter-tall furry humanoids native to the Outer Rim desert world of Tatooine. Jawas who migrated from Tatooine were referred to as Offworld Jawas. 
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Jawa
87.name: Jawas

88.content:
Tusken Raiders, less formally referred to as Sand People or simply as Tuskens, were a culture of nomadic sentients indigenous to the desert planet Tatooine, where they were often hostile to local settlers. Tusken children were called Uli-ah. The name of Tusken Raiders was acquired much later, due to a period of concerted attacks on the settlement called Fort Tusken around eight decades before 19 BBY.

One tribe captured the bounty hunter Boba Fett, but they accepted him into their tribe after he had proved his worth to them. 

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Tusken_Raider
88.name: Sand People

89.content:
Rodians were a reptilian humanoid species native to Rodia in the Tyrius system. Highly recognizable due to characteristics in facial structure and skin pigment, Rodians were infamous for their violent culture, which sprang from the difficulties of life in the jungles of their homeworld. Though they were often relegated to the fringes of galactic society as bounty hunters or criminal henchmen, Rodians were not merely simple-minded thugs. The Rodian people managed to produce artists, merchants, and politicians who were found even among the upper classes of the Core Worlds. 
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Rodian/Legends
89.name: Rodian

90.content:
Geonosians, often called bugs in clone trooper slang, were an insectoid species native to the planet Geonosis. Geonosians resided in catacomb-like hive colonies beneath the organic-looking spires.

Notable Geonosians included Poggle the Lesser, Gizor Dellso, and Sun Fac, who all held important roles in the Confederacy of Independent Systems.

The Geonosians, with their long snouts and spindly limbs, bore a certain resemblance to B1-Series battle droids, which they manufactured for some time before the outbreak of the Clone Wars. 

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Geonosian/Legends
90.name: Zelosian

91.content:
The Hutts were a sentient species of large gastropods[6] with short arms, wide cavernous mouths and huge eyes, who controlled a large space empire in Hutt Space. The species was said to originally hail from the planet Varl, but no planet by that name appeared on any Imperial star charts. Their adopted homeworld was Nal Hutta. Members of this species were often stereotyped as crime lords. 
For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Hutt/Legends
91.name: Hutt

92.content:
The Confederacy of Independent Systems, abbreviated to CIS, and otherwise known as the Separatist Alliance, the Separatist State, the Separatist Confederacy, or simply referred to as the Separatists, was a united galaxy-wide confederacy formed of outlaying star systems from the Galactic Republic, a democratic union, whom the Confederacy had opposed following a period of political turmoil. Established by fallen Jedi Master Count Dooku of the planet Serenno, who served as its Head of State, the Confederacy was founded from a belief of excessive taxation and corruption within the Republic's Galactic Senate, as well as a general feeling of dissatisfaction towards and neglect by the Republic-centric Core Worlds region of the galaxy. Furthermore, the Confederacy was secretly supported by several major galactic corporations which formed the Confederacy's executive council, including the Trade Federation, led by Viceroy Nute Gunray; the Stalgasin hive, led by Archduke Poggle the Lesser; the InterGalactic Banking Clan, headed by Chairman San Hill; the Techno Union, led by Foreman Wat Tambor; the Commerce Guild, led by Presidente Shu Mai; the Corporate Alliance, led by Magistrate Passel Argente; and the Retail Caucus.

In 24 BBY, a political crisis had begun which led to escalating tensions between the reigning Republic and the rising Confederacy, established in a galaxy-wide secessionist movement orchestrated by Dooku. Many within the Confederacy, including its parliament of senators, had no desire in fighting their adversaries, as they sought to be free of what they saw as the corruption and tyranny of the Republic. However, in 22 BBY, both governments and their respective military forces became enmeshed in the pan-galactic Clone Wars that had erupted on the planet Geonosis, the first major conflict in a millennium.

In the following three years of the war, which had raged across the entire galaxy on several fronts, the Confederacy made rapid attempts to cease the Republic's influence. However, unknown to the galaxy or either side, the war was a ploy designed by the Dark Lord of the Sith, Darth Sidious, who led both the Confederacy through Dooku as his Sith Master, and, secretly, the Republic as Supreme Chancellor Sheev Palpatine. The Sith Lord had managed to deceive both parties. By the third year of the war, the Confederacy had suffered several major defeats in the Outer Rim Sieges as the conflict began to approach its end, while the CIS lost many starships in the decisive Battle of Coruscant, which also resulted in the death of Dooku. In the days following their defeat at Coruscant, General Grievous was neutralized on the planet Utapau, leading to the collapse of the Separatist leadership, and the fighting effectively coming to an end.

Following both the Jedi's demise and rise of the Galactic Empire, Viceroy Nute Gunray and the other surviving leaders gathered on the planet Mustafar with hopes of securing peace with the newly rising Empire ruled by Galactic Emperor Darth Sidious. However he sent his new apprentice Darth Vader to wipe out them and deactivate the Separatist Droid Army as a threat to his Empire.

With the end of the Clone Wars, the newly-formed Galactic Empire as the successor to the Old Republic, began to dismantle and absorb the former Confederacy of Independent Systems, with only several holdouts daring to resist the Empire, which were suppressed. But an idealized view of the cause persisted during the Imperial Era, with some still holding secessionist tendencies, even into the Galactic Civil War.

For more information: https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Confederacy_of_Independent_Systems
92.name: The Confederacy of Independent Systems

93.content:
The Galactic Republic, also known as the Grand Republic or simply as the Republic, was a democratic federal union spread across light-years of space. Old Republic and first Galactic Republic were terms affixed to the pre-modern Republic that existed until 1032 BBY, with the Old Republic also referring to the modern Republic that was supplanted by the Galactic Empire in 19 BBY. In addition, the term High Republic denoted the era in which the Republic reached the zenith of its power, lasting from around 500 BBY to around 100 BBY. The Republic was founded many millennia before the Battle of Yavin, approximately 25,000 BBY, around the same time as the Jedi Order.
